data_findings.finding: jonathanchan kernel: Ensemble approach - collect best configuration for each N from multiple sources (bucket-of-chump, SmartManoj GitHub, telegram-public-shared-solution, etc.). Uses sa_v1_parallel.cpp with -n 15000 -r 5 parameters. Key techniques: SA with fractional translation (0.001 to 0.00001 step sizes), perturb function to escape local optima, ls_v3 local search.

bbox3.cpp optimizer: Uses Complex Number Vector Coordination, Fluid Dynamics, Hinge Pivot, Density Gradient Flow, Global Boundary Tension. Has aggressive_repair for overlap resolution. Key parameters: -n (iterations), -r (rounds). Uses OpenMP for parallelization.

tree_packer_v21.cpp: Swap moves, Multi-angle restarts, Higher temperature SA, Backward propagation (bp.cpp). Uses squeeze, compaction, localSearch. bp.exe removes trees from larger configs to improve smaller ones. Parameters: -n (iterations), -r (rounds).
Pre-optimized submissions baseline: bucket-of-chump/submission.csv scores 70.647327, smartmanoj_submission.csv scores 70.743774. Target is 68.894234, gap of ~1.75 points (2.5%).

Small N values dominate score contribution: N=1 contributes 0.661, N=2 contributes 0.451, N=3 contributes 0.435. Top 10 N values (1-9, 15) contribute ~4.0 points out of 70.65 total. Improving small N values has outsized impact.

Ensemble of all available CSVs scores 70.647327 - same as best single file (submission.csv). This means submission.csv already has the best configuration for ALL 200 N values. Standard optimization approaches have hit a local optimum.

Discussion insights: 'Why the winning solutions will be Asymmetric' (38 votes) - asymmetric layouts outperform symmetric for large N. 'Symmetric solutions that are apparently optimal' (43 votes) - symmetric may be optimal for small N only.
